message: how about an app that can help people find a seat in this room?
dr nic's network graph in node?
that'd have to be some kind of distributed network set up with arduino's and pressure sensors on the seats brah
or a tool to build tools to help people find seats in rooms
there was some paper/talk at stanford with some lightweight robot with mapping the network from the room of the seats etc. i'm lazy and dont remember what it's called (@technoweenie )
there's an app like that for parking spaces http://sfpark.org/
I'd be down for working on a python port of the metrics library.
i've got the basics in a javascript library, but it isn't anywhere near as useful as coda's metrics
Is anyone working on the "available seat" app in earnest?
need to spend some quality time getting the algorithms better
Metrics in ruby
We should make CodaHale's Metrics into a <ruby gem | python egg | whatevs>
@kasper agreed
To use the same algorithms as https://github.com/codahale/metrics/tree/development/src/main/java/com/yammer/metrics
I want to add better maths to ReinH's ruby statsd library: https://github.com/reinh/statsd/blob/master/lib/statsd.rb
so in theory, could you put a camera at the back of the room, tape bright green|<color> placards in front of each seat, and use opencv to judge which seats are empty by which placards are obscured?
Metrics in ruby
yaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay build build build go go go
If anyone hacks anything cool up, remember i blog for the changelog, so i'd love to give you coverage.
@mtodd are you just saying you're working on that in earnest, or are you just saying it should be done?

not necessarily a port of @coda's Metrics
but maybe :)
